title: Why do people like musicals? - Quora

response.answer_text: Musicals represent a heightened, magical world which is not like our realistic world that we live from day to day. Therefore, experiencing a musical is an escape into a different, more interesting, more sonically beautiful place. Musicals are best viewed in the theater. They tend not to work as well in film - because our expectation of film is that it is a more realistic expression. Musicals require a certain amount of freedom to imagine worlds which are unlike our own. They inhabit a world of heightened passions and heightened emotions where people are thrust into song by the events of the play. This freedom gives musicals some wonderful advantages over other forms of storytelling. First, song itself allows for a more emotional exploration of the character’s inner feelings. That’s why shows like Spring Awakening can be set in Germany of 1890, but then use modern Rock music to communicate the inner thoughts of the high-school students in the play. Second, the song in a musical is like a close-up in a movie. When you get a movie close-up, you see small emotional changes in the actor’s face, and these communicate emotion. On stage, there is no such thing as a close up. The audience sees an actor on stage who is, you know, hundreds of feet away. How do you do a close-up? Well, a song is a fantastic way to do a close-up on stage. They sing their emotions and you get a close-up view of what the character is feeling - through music - which you would be unable to get in the same way as a movie close-up. And because it is a musical, you accept that they can sing about their feelings (because that’s what songs are - they are people singing about emotions). A couple of awesome examples are ‘And I Am Telling You I’m Not Going’ in Dreamgirls, and Billy’s ‘Soliloquy’ from Carousel. And finally, musicals are amazing at expressing ‘the will of the community’. How can a work of art express the feeling of a group of people? It is really hard. Musicals accomplish this by having actors singing as a group (a chorus). This gives voice to the community in such a powerful way that is practically impossible in any other medium. As an example, watch ‘The Music Man’ (the songs ‘Iowa Stubborn’ and ‘(Ya Got) Trouble’). I’m not sure that any of this description will help you enjoy musicals. I used to have a friend who hated Star Wars because ‘It’s not realistic’. All art work, to some extent, requires you to relax a bit and enter the world being presented to you. This is one reason why I believe that modern movie-musicals generally do not work. The social contract between the musical and the audience (which is born of the theater experience) is different than the social contract between a movie and the audience. To enjoy a musical, you must agree to enter this heightened, emotional sonic world and accept it (temporarily) as ‘truth’. If you want to try it out, I *strongly* recommend you see it in the theater, live. Musicals work best, by a large margin, in the context of the theater experience. If all you ever do is watch them on TV or in a movie theater, then it is a much tougher sell. Long winded, I know. I hope this was helpful.
